reviewText:
NASCAR '15 feels like a game that could improve in every aspect. For example, the replay system works, and is even fairly good despite some bugs, yet it could be miles better. It could give you a free cam or the ability to focus on other cars outside of yours, just to name two examples. On the same vein, the painting mode is barebones, and is complicated and difficult to use, even after figuring it out.

Where NASCAR '15 shines however, is it's gameplay. It is pretty good for a racing game on the keyboard and the tracks all offer unique and different challenges. You might be extremely good at Texas, yet fail miserably at Kansas. Thus is the parity and challenge of NASCAR '15. Yet even the driving doesn't escape my earlier complaint: being lackluster. Most of the game's depth comes from tweaking your car, changing setups, adding wedge, addcing tape, et cetera. But none of those things are adequatlely explained. How are you supposed to know what adding or removing tape does to the car unless you are a diehard fan or an areodynamics fanatic?

One last point is about the multiplayer, specifically private matches with a few close friends. It sucks. Again, it is hard to figure out how to even set it up correctly, and then you JUST race against your friends. There is no option to turn on A.I. None. It would be fine in my eyes, if there was a setting I could change. Sometimes, you just want to race your buddy with the A.I. but you simply can't do that; it's 1v1 or however many friends you have, and that's just the way it is.

Overall, NASCAR '15 is an adequate racing game, yet suffers from not being as good as it COULD have been. It feels like a poor console game slapped onto PC and then forgotten about. I would recommend it if you were going to have a few fun hours with friends, but on it's own it is not a very good game. At best, I would describe this game as average, for $20.00 though, you can't be THAT wrong. 5/10.

reviewText:
When you buy a NASCAR game, you expect to make a lot of left turns. But this game fails to deliver even that; the basis for any NASCAR videogame.

As a big fan of the sport, I knew exactly what I was getting into when I bought this game. I had seen reviews, seen gameplay, and played the Xbox 360 version myself as a rental back when the game was called NASCAR '14. I saw it listed on here for only $10 so I figured hey, why not give it a try?

Right off the bat I turned the music and voiceovers off. The music was terrible, pandering to the stereotypical NASCAR fan, who may have enjoyed it. This is a non-issue; turn it off and be done with it. Same with the voice, both on menus and the in-game spotter. The spotter was annoying and not realistic and the voiceover in the menus was simply unnecessary. After a few graphical tweaks, I was ready to take my car on the track and run a few laps at my local track, Phoenix International Raceway.

As far as driving goes, this game is solid. But that's as far as positives go. The camera angles are odd, none feel right to use on a PC. I had to play with a controller because the game is simply not optimised for keyboard + mouse. Fine, I thought, I'll keep trying. When I started a race at PIR I was immediately reminded of this games horrible AI. They will race you like it's the final lap at Daytona... Every single lap. Pack racing is the only option. The field does not spread out at all, which may be fine for people who are not huge into NASCAR, but for me, it was a massive problem.

At this point I started the career, thinking maybe the pack racing would be better at restrictor plate tracks. After a decent test session at Indianapolis I participated in the first race of my career. Restrictor plate racing at Daytona was almost unplayable. Between not being able to hold a lane and constantly having the AI try to run me off the track, I found myself rewinding from a crash every lap.

Now on to the crashes. As far as a physics engine goes, this is one of the worst I've seen. At Daytona, crashes are minor and involve on car spinning and collecting other cars, which are somehow able to continue as if nothing happened. Hitting the wall does very little damage to the car, and when the cosmetic damage does get triggered by impacts it looks terrible, like a small child was rubbing the paint off a toy car on cement or with very minor collapsing. I don't ask for much when it comes to crashes. I'd like mildly realistic damage or a good crashing physics engine. This game has neither. Another thing I noticed is that, with any minor impact into the wall, the crowd roars, but is essentially silent at any other time. This, while realistic, was another inconsistency that bothered me.

NASCAR '15 Victory Edition has decent graphics, but the lighting in-game is so absurdly unrealistic that it completely ruins it. Its as if someone bumped the contrast up to high, changed the color temperature, and somehow made every car have a matte finish. The screenshots clearly show this. In the garage, on the menus, and at certain tracks, the cars look excellent. But at other times they, too, completely fail to deliver.

Racing games need to run smoothly in order for it to be a good experience. This game also fails to do that. I encountered a framerate issue when controlling the car from the third-person perspective in that it seems the car is rendered at a stable 60 FPS, but the environments - including opponent vehicles - render below that framerate and suffer from constant drops. It detracts immensely from the experience and makes it difficult to race.

When it comes to sound, this game is not that bad. Engine sounds are decent. My only gripe with this would be that crashing into anything always makes the same dull bumping noise, and it doesn't sound remotely appropriate for stock cars. It sounds like bumper cars which, when paired with the less-than-optimal AI, is pretty much all this game is anyway.

One positive I found playing NASCAR '15 Victory Edition was the UI. The menus were crisp and nice looking, sounds were not bad, and KB+M/controller usage in menus was well designed. Because this game is simply a port a lot of menus had the typical ABXY buttons from an Xbox 360 controller. When playing with a controller, this was fine. With a mouse? Not so much.

I did encounter a game-breaking glitch while playing though. Other reviewers mentioned this too, but using ALT+TAB to get out the game effectively breaks the graphics engine. Unless you play in windowed mode (which I personally dislike, but whatever) there does not seem to be a fix for this issue. It requires a restart, sets the game to a very low default resolution, and does not automatically correct itself. Frankly I am astonished a bug like this is in a finished game, but at this point I'm not even suprised.

In the end, save your money. Other reviewers list the $10 price tag as a pro, but its still too much to spend on a broken, half-hearted, unrealistic NASCAR game. There are better options out there. Hopefully DMR's new NASCAR game (NASCAR Heat: Evolution) is good, but I rarely have high hopes for NASCAR games anymore. Looks like I will stick to iRacing for now.

reviewText:
This game is terrible, even within the already-low bar of crappy NASCAR titles that came before it.

1- It changes settings on you regularly and without warning. When running in windowed mode, it will change resolution each time you launch, even if you don't change it back manually. And if you don't, you're dumb, because it picks tiny tiny windows for you. It also seems to change race settings if you exit between sessions: I quit after qualifying for a race, came back for the actual race, and apparently caution flags had been turned off.

2- For whatever ungodly reason, yellow flags are off by default. Having an option to turn them off is perhaps understandable, but off by default? I cannot comprehend where that decision came from, and it WILL surprise people not looking for the setting. In fact, looks like the top discussion on Steam is about this.

3- WTF is with cautions in this game? Another car taps me, I get a little sideways and recover, car behind me spins out, yellow flag... then I'm back to the back of the field somehow? Why? How? I kept it together, what am I being punished for? And the consistency of this is maddening. Even when I know I came out the wreckage in the 20s, it drops me back to 43. Every time.

4- It's just an ugly game. Aside from having less blocky models, this is no better than early xbox 360 era stuff. Textures on everything seem rather amateur hour. And while the car models are ok, the track is terrible and the up close shots of my pit-crew's butts when I roll up for fuel displays some truly dire models and textures. Which is kind of inexcusable for a game wherein the graphics trumps basically all other features except for weak gameplay. Speaking of...

5- I know NASCAR tends to be just parades these days anyway but come on, you had a chance to break up the sport's inherent monotony and you didnt. Even zipping around playing car-pinball is boring.

6- Yes, there is an option to turn the music volume to 0. This somehow seems insufficient to remove the way-too-cliche country soundtrack: I want it burned. I want the Earth salted behind it. I want music that's interesting and perhaps inspirational, rather than just stereotyping this sport down to the bone.

7- Also can't skip or remove the intro flashcards. I mean I get preventing us from removing them, but still gotta sit through them? Really? Inexcusable these days.

8- NASCAR sucks lol

Honestly, this is terrible. I got it on sale on a whim after spending some time with younger cousins playing one of the old EA ones over Thanksgiving, and hand-on-heart, this crap almost makes me nostalgic for some of that EA rubber-band AI magic. Or the pointless rivals crap.

If you're a fan of NASCAR, my review will be meaningless to you. If you're a racing fan looking at giving it a shot, do not. Do NOT. It's simply not worth it. I see that my fighting with the changing settings has bumped me over the 2 hour gametime refund time limit, so welp, there goes my $10. You, child, you can still escape this.

reviewText: Essentially an update to Nascar 14, no major changes, but it's still a blast. That is, if you have a racing wheel. I haven't logged too many hours into this game, but my opinion is that playing this game with the keyboard is near impossible. I won the pole position of the Daytona 500. it wasnt hard to drive without other cars on the track. But come race day, it was impossible to race alongside other cars. this is because you cannot simply go into a turn at 175 miles an hour, you need to decelerate so that you do not run into other cars. With the keyboard, there is no way to smoothly decelerate and then maintain a certain speed. Thus, coming out of a turn, you either crash, or fall behind the pack. Another example. Martinsville speedway, the paperclip. You are constantly next to other cars, accelerating and decelerating due to how short the track is. Without pedals, you cannot maintain a speed behind another car and you let go of the gas, slow down, and then either hit the car behind you or fall behind the pack. I love Nascar and have a racing wheel coming tomorrow so that I can play it and Formula One. The career mode walks you through the Sprint Cup series, every single race, and as you progress, you can upgrade your car and earn new sponsors whose decals can be added to your car. I recommend it if you have a wheel or use a game pad maybe, but with the keyboard, you simply will not enjoy this or get to truly race next to other cars and be competitive.

reviewText:
NASCAR '15 Victory Edition is a game that I find most enjoyable playing from time to time. Then again, I am only a casual NASCAR fan, and the hard-core race fan is more likely to invest endless amounts of time into this game. Prior to purchasing this game, I've read a majority of comments, good and bad, to assess the legitimacy of this game. I feel that most of the negativity stems from the balls to the wall hard-core NASCAR fans. And those type of fans tend to complain about the minor things such as: lack of customization options, lack of commentary, repetitive commentary, and the inability to use a headset.
My two major complaints are the online aspect(s), or the lack thereof, and the physics of damaged cars. Lets begin with online gaming. In NASCAR '15, the AI is not bad. I have adjusted the difficulty level(s), as well as the number of laps, to the maximum levels. As a result, the AI acts realistically and accordingly, especially when I'm in the middle of a large group of cars. To be the best driver on the track, I've had to work my a** off, and I love that fact. There is no better feeling than knowing I earned a win against the best of the best; guys like Dale Earnhardt, Jr. and Jeff Gordon.
However, no AI comes close to holding a candle to playing against real people. I want to play my entire career against other people. How awesome would it be to race against 42 other people every time? That would be the ultimate gaming experience.
Sports games such as NASCAR and Madden Football  would be untouchable if franchise mode or career mode was available online. Some might say that such a thing is simply too much or impossible, but I disagree.
As for the physics, my only complaint is that AI controlled cars are capable of racing in-spite of their car receiving extensive physical damage to their car. I feel like it takes an act of God for AI controlled drivers to suffer from heavy damage.  Yet, the gamer will experiences the opposite effect of such physical damage to his or her car. Those who've played NASCAR '15 know exactly what I'm talking about. LMFAO!
In closing, I recommend purchasing this game. Most people will get a fair amount of enjoyment out of this game. At $9.99 + tax, this game is dirt cheap and worth adding to your collection. You may find some minor things to be unhappy about. However, the minor issues are worth overlooking. Personally, the two major complaints I discussed are the only real hangups of this game.
